speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: SCENE I. A street in Westminster.

speaker: CARDINAL WOLSEY
text_entry: Enter two Gentlemen, meeting one another

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: You're well met once again.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: So are you.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: You come to take your stand here, and behold

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: The Lady Anne pass from her coronation?

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 'Tis all my business. At our last encounter,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The Duke of Buckingham came from his trial.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: 'Tis very true: but that time offer'd sorrow;

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: This, general joy.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 'Tis well: the citizens,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: I am sure, have shown at full their royal minds--

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: As, let 'em have their rights, they are ever forward--

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: In celebration of this day with shows,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Pageants and sights of honour.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Never greater,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Nor, I'll assure you, better taken, sir.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: May I be bold to ask at what that contains,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: That paper in your hand?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Yes; 'tis the list

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Of those that claim their offices this day

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: By custom of the coronation.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: The Duke of Suffolk is the first, and claims

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: To be high-steward; next, the Duke of Norfolk,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: He to be earl marshal: you may read the rest.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: I thank you, sir: had I not known those customs,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: I should have been beholding to your paper.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: But, I beseech you, what's become of Katharine,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The princess dowager? how goes her business?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: That I can tell you too. The Archbishop

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Of Canterbury, accompanied with other

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Learned and reverend fathers of his order,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Held a late court at Dunstable, six miles off

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: From Ampthill where the princess lay; to which

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: She was often cited by them, but appear'd not:

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: And, to be short, for not appearance and

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: The king's late scruple, by the main assent

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Of all these learned men she was divorced,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: And the late marriage made of none effect

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Since which she was removed to Kimbolton,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Where she remains now sick.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Alas, good lady!

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Trumpets

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The trumpets sound: stand close, the queen is coming.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Hautboys

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: THE ORDER OF THE CORONATION

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 1. A lively flourish of Trumpets.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 2. Then, two Judges.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 3. Lord Chancellor, with the purse and mace

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: before him.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 4. Choristers, singing.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Music

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 5. Mayor of London, bearing the mace. Then

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Garter, in his coat of arms, and on his

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: head a gilt copper crown.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 6. Marquess Dorset, bearing a sceptre of gold,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: on his head a demi-coronal of gold. With

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: him, SURREY, bearing the rod of silver with

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: the dove, crowned with an earl's coronet.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Collars of SS.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 7. SUFFOLK, in his robe of estate, his coronet

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: on his head, bearing a long white wand, as

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: high-steward. With him, NORFOLK, with the

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: rod of marshalship, a coronet on his head.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Collars of SS.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 8. A canopy borne by four of the Cinque-ports;

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: under it, QUEEN ANNE in her robe; in her hair

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: richly adorned with pearl, crowned. On each

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: side her, the Bishops of London and

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Winchester.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 9. The old Duchess of Norfolk, in a coronal of

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: gold, wrought with flowers, bearing QUEEN

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: ANNE's train.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: 10. Certain Ladies or Countesses, with plain

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: circlets of gold without flowers.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: They pass over the stage in order and state

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: A royal train, believe me. These I know:

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Who's that that bears the sceptre?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Marquess Dorset:

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: And that the Earl of Surrey, with the rod.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: A bold brave gentleman. That should be

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The Duke of Suffolk?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: 'Tis the same: high-steward.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: And that my Lord of Norfolk?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Yes;

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Heaven bless thee!

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Looking on QUEEN ANNE

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Thou hast the sweetest face I ever look'd on.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Sir, as I have a soul, she is an angel;

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Our king has all the Indies in his arms,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: And more and richer, when he strains that lady:

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: I cannot blame his conscience.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: They that bear

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: The cloth of honour over her, are four barons

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Of the Cinque-ports.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Those men are happy; and so are all are near her.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: I take it, she that carries up the train

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Is that old noble lady, Duchess of Norfolk.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: It is; and all the rest are countesses.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Their coronets say so. These are stars indeed;

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: And sometimes falling ones.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: No more of that.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Exit procession, and then a great flourish of trumpets

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Enter a third Gentleman

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: God save you, sir! where have you been broiling?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Among the crowd i' the Abbey; where a finger

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Could not be wedged in more: I am stifled

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: With the mere rankness of their joy.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: You saw

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The ceremony?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: That I did.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: How was it?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Well worth the seeing.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Good sir, speak it to us.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: As well as I am able. The rich stream

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Of lords and ladies, having brought the queen

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: To a prepared place in the choir, fell off

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: A distance from her; while her grace sat down

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: To rest awhile, some half an hour or so,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: In a rich chair of state, opposing freely

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: The beauty of her person to the people.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Believe me, sir, she is the goodliest woman

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: That ever lay by man: which when the people

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Had the full view of, such a noise arose

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: As the shrouds make at sea in a stiff tempest,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: As loud, and to as many tunes: hats, cloaks--

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Doublets, I think,--flew up; and had their faces

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Been loose, this day they had been lost. Such joy

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: I never saw before. Great-bellied women,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: That had not half a week to go, like rams

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: In the old time of war, would shake the press,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: And make 'em reel before 'em. No man living

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Could say 'This is my wife' there; all were woven

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: So strangely in one piece.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: But, what follow'd?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: At length her grace rose, and with modest paces

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Came to the altar; where she kneel'd, and saint-like

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Cast her fair eyes to heaven and pray'd devoutly.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Then rose again and bow'd her to the people:

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: When by the Archbishop of Canterbury

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: She had all the royal makings of a queen;

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: As holy oil, Edward Confessor's crown,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: The rod, and bird of peace, and all such emblems

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Laid nobly on her: which perform'd, the choir,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: With all the choicest music of the kingdom,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Together sung 'Te Deum.' So she parted,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: And with the same full state paced back again

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: To York-place, where the feast is held.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Sir,

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: You must no more call it York-place, that's past;

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: For, since the cardinal fell, that title's lost:

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: 'Tis now the king's, and call'd Whitehall.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: I know it;

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: But 'tis so lately alter'd, that the old name

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Is fresh about me.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: What two reverend bishops

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Were those that went on each side of the queen?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Stokesly and Gardiner; the one of Winchester,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Newly preferr'd from the king's secretary,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: The other, London.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: He of Winchester

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Is held no great good lover of the archbishop's,

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: The virtuous Cranmer.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: All the land knows that:

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: However, yet there is no great breach; when it comes,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Cranmer will find a friend will not shrink from him.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: Who may that be, I pray you?

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Thomas Cromwell;

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: A man in much esteem with the king, and truly

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: A worthy friend. The king has made him master

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: O' the jewel house,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: And one, already, of the privy council.

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: He will deserve more.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Yes, without all doubt.

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Come, gentlemen, ye shall go my way, which

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Is to the court, and there ye shall be my guests:

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: Something I can command. As I walk thither,

speaker: Third Gentleman
text_entry: I'll tell ye more.

speaker: Both
text_entry: You may command us, sir.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Exeunt
